text.content:
Worlds are an Actor type which represent worlds and systems within the game. Traveller mixes the idea of a 'World' and a 'Star System' together, and the same is done here.

By default, when a World actor is created, its prototype token is defined as being linked to the Actor object.

To be useful, Worlds need to be visible to players. However, they don't need write permissions in order to use most of their facilities.

Usage

Word actors are designed to be used in the following situations:

  • Representing a world within the game, and displaying basic information about it. It would be possible to use a Journal entry for this, but having an Actor allows a token to be placed on a map.

  • Trade is possible directly with a world. Trade goods can be bought and sold from a world by players, by dragging goods from the World sheet to a Spacecraft sheet.

Future Plans

  • Using them as a shop for buying goods.

  • Tracking Patrons and other 'things of interest'

  • Linking to Traveller Map

The Mongoose Traveller trade system is implemented within Foundry. The idea is that players should for the most part be able to manage trade themselves, without having to refer to the GM.

Unless a player has write permission to a world, a GM does need to be logged in whilst trade is being performed. The GM is also needed to 're-roll' what trade goods are available.

Factions represent internal divisions on a world. They may be political groups, corporations, religions or nations that are separate from the main government. See the @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e-core.mgt2e-core-docs.JournalEntry.mLitXfWxiPePWZDd.JournalEntryPage.3NiSuEt71bB7qoTx#rivals,-factions,-connections-and-colonies]{World and Universe Creation} chapter of the core rulebook.

Each faction has a strength (from Obscure to Overwhelming), as well as its own government type.

If a world has no factions defined, then when the Generate button is pressed on a world, a set of random factions will be generated.

Faction Tables

In the MgT2e Base Tables compendium pack, thre is a folder named @UUID[Compendium.mgt2e.base-tables.Folder.iSwBLLghzu3fo1Bz]{Faction Generator}. This contains a roll table which is used to generate some simple random faction descriptions.

When a faction is created, this table will be used to generate text for the faction.

If you copy the folder to your world, that the local copy of this folder will be used instead, allowing you to modify and expand the list of factions that will be used.

The generator will look for a roll table named 'Factions X', where X is the government code of the faction (from 0 to 12). If one is not found, then it will simply look for the 'Factions' table in that folder.

If you want an internationalised version of the tables, then add the language code to the name of the folder, e.g. "Faction Generator es" for a Spanish translation of the tables.

V13

There are differences in how RollTables are used between Foundry v12 and v13. In v12, a roll table simply has a text field. This is used in the description of the faction.

In v13, they have a name and a description. If you are using v13 you can make use of this for finer grained control over the factions.

The name is copied into the name of the faction, and the description is copied into the description. Any secret text will only be displayed to the owner of a world.

Patrons represent interesting people on a world who make provide jobs or plot hooks for the players. Patrons may be marked as private, in which case only the owner of the world can see them.

Patrons are not full NPCs, they simply have some basic information (name, species and profession) along with a description.
